statement.text: The smallest detectable energy quanta are single photons. While the Planck energy is enormous (~10⁹ J), single-photon detectors routinely detect photons with energies as small as ~10⁻²⁴ J (microwave) to ~10⁻¹⁹ J (visible). The cosmic microwave background contains photons of ~10⁻²³ J each. There is NO fundamental minimum energy in physics—wavelengths can be arbitrarily long, making photon energies arbitrarily small. The practical limit is set by thermal noise: E_thermal = k_B T ≈ 4 × 10⁻²¹ J at room temperature.
statement.formal: Single photon: E = hν = hc/λ; Visible: ~3 × 10⁻¹⁹ J; CMB: ~6 × 10⁻²³ J; Radio: ~10⁻²⁸ J possible; Thermal limit: k_B T ≈ 4 × 10⁻²¹ J (300K)

key_values.planck_energy_comparison: 1.96 × 10⁹ J (10²⁸ times larger than visible photon)

explanation.intuition: Unlike mass, there is no 'smallest energy'—photons can have arbitrarily small energies by having arbitrarily long wavelengths. A radio wave photon has ~10⁻²⁸ J, while a gamma ray has ~10⁻¹³ J. The Planck energy (~2 GJ, energy of a large bomb) is definitely NOT the minimum—it's the scale where quantum gravity becomes important.
explanation.key_insight: Energy detection limits come from: (1) Thermal noise (k_B T sets the floor for energy discrimination), (2) Detector quantum efficiency (single photon detection requires E > detector bandgap), (3) Shot noise from photon statistics. Modern superconducting detectors achieve single-photon sensitivity at microwave frequencies (~10⁻²⁴ J), approaching thermal limits at mK temperatures.
explanation.technical_details: Single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs) detect visible photons (~10⁻¹⁹ J). Superconducting nanowire detectors work in infrared (~10⁻²⁰ J). Transition edge sensors (TES) can detect single microwave photons (~10⁻²⁴ J) when cooled to mK. The cosmic microwave background at 2.7 K contains ~10¹⁰ photons per cubic meter, each with ~0.4 meV energy.
theoretical_limits: No fundamental minimum energy—E = hν can be arbitrarily small as ν → 0
Thermal noise: Cannot distinguish energies < k_B T without cooling
Quantum fluctuations: Zero-point energy ½ℏω per mode
Gravitational decoherence proposed at Δm·c² scale over time

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck energy is where quantum gravity matters—NOT a minimum. It equals the energy of ~10²⁸ visible photons or ~40 liters of gasoline.

related.relationship: Planck energy is NOT minimum—it's 10²⁸ times larger than a visible photon

sources.citation: Hadfield, R.H. (2009): Single-photon detectors for optical quantum information applications

learning_objectives: Understand that photon energy can be arbitrarily small (no minimum)
Know that Planck energy is enormous, not a minimum
Appreciate thermal noise as practical energy detection limit
common_misconceptions: Planck energy is NOT the minimum—it's ~2 GJ, an enormous energy
There is no 'smallest energy' quantum—photons have E = hν with ν → 0 possible
Zero-point energy (½ℏω) is not 'minimum detectable'—it's quantum vacuum fluctuation
